title: 114_hr5910
content: The Act titled "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group. The "Improving Economic Sanctions Act of 2016" establishes an Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury to report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Group includes the Undersecretary of the Treasury for Terrorism and Financial Crimes as chairperson and senior representatives selected by the Undersecretary. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group within the Department of the Treasury includes senior representatives from various offices and bureaus to conduct contingency planning for the rapid imposition, monitoring, and enforcement of sanctions by the Office of Foreign Assets Control. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group at the Department of the Treasury conducts contingency planning for the rapid imposition, monitoring, and enforcement of economic sanctions against a foreign country or entity. Considerations include the vulnerability of the target and the effectiveness of different types of sanctions on their economy. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group at the Department of the Treasury evaluates the effectiveness of economic sanctions on a foreign country or entity, considering factors such as the impact on the US economy, the possibility of imposing sanctions with limited costs, the effectiveness of unilateral vs. multilateral sanctions, and the process for lifting sanctions. The Group also reviews each economic sanctions program to improve US economic sanctions policy. The Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group at the Department of the Treasury aims to review and identify problems with existing economic sanctions programs administered by the Office of Foreign Assets Control. They also develop strategies to improve these programs and overall United States economic sanctions policy. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes is responsible for coordinating the development of these strategies. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes coordinates United States economic sanctions policy with various government departments and ensures information sharing. The Group must meet at least once per month. The Undersecretary for Terrorism and Financial Crimes can assign Treasury personnel to assist the Group. The Group may consult with experts from academia, research organizations, and the private sector. The Group must submit annual reports to Congress. The Senate and House committees will submit a report to Congress including an overview of contingency planning, identified problems, strategy, interagency coordination, and consulted policy experts. The Senate and House committees will submit a report to Congress including an overview of contingency planning, identified problems, strategy, interagency coordination, consulted policy experts, and a comprehensive sanctions impact assessment. The assessment may use various social scientific research methods. The report to Congress will assess economic sanctions programs, including their impact on foreign and US economies, and behavioral changes of targeted entities. It will utilize social scientific research methods such as quantitative and qualitative research, econometrics, and formal modeling. It will utilize social scientific research methods for each assessment, which will be made publicly available on the Department of the Treasury's website. The United States economic sanctions policy is developed, implemented, monitored, enforced, and lifted by the Department of the Treasury. A new Economic Sanctions Strategy, Coordination, and Planning Group will report directly to the Secretary of the Treasury.
